Legal_Issue: Was the Officer's decision reasonable, and did it breach procedural fairness by not granting an oral interview?
Evidence_Assessment: Insufficient evidence of disproportionate hardship if returned to Korea; psychologist's opinion on Korea was unverified; Officer inferred family support in Korea based on past support
Decision_Outcome: Refusal of humanitarian and compassionate (H&C) application
Credibility_Factor: Psychologist's opinion considered but deemed unverified
Legal_Rule: Standard of review for H&C decisions is reasonableness; procedural fairness does not always require an oral hearing
Procedural_Issue: Alleged breach of procedural fairness due to lack of oral interview
Grounds_for_Claim: Humanitarian and compassionate grounds based on abuse in Canada, divorce, loss of sponsorship
Outcome_on_Merits: Officer found insufficient hardship to justify relief
Procedural_Fairness_Assessment: No breach of procedural fairness; oral interview not required
Key_Evidence_Considered: History of abuse in Canada, divorce, loss of sponsorship, psychological report, family ties in Korea
Legal_Framework: Humanitarian and Compassionate (H&C) provisions under IRPA
Applicant_Challenge: Refusal of H&C application and denial of oral interview
Legal_Rule_Source: Federal Court jurisprudence on standard of review and procedural fairness
Defendant_Response: Officer's assessment that hardship was not disproportionate and procedural fairness upheld
Evidence_Type: Documentary evidence, psychological assessment, personal affidavits
Remedy_Requested: Certification of a serious question and overturning of refusal
Claimant_Status: Former sponsored spouse, now independent applicant on H&C grounds
Governing_Rule: Reasonableness standard and principles of procedural fairness
